description: From Middle English clokken, clocken, from Old English cloccian (“to cluck, make a noise”), from Proto-Germanic *klukkwōną (“to make a sound, cluck”), of imitative origin. Cognate with Scots clok, clock (“to cluck”), Dutch klokken (“to cluck”), Low German klucken (“to cluck”), German glucken (“to cluck”), Danish klukke (“to cluck”), Swedish klucka (“to cluck”), Icelandic klökkva (“to sob, whine, cluck”).

entries.meaning: The sound made by a hen, especially when brooding, or calling her chicks.
A kind of tongue click used to urge on a horse.

verbs.description: cluck (third-person singular simple present clucks, present participle clucking, simple past and past participle clucked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (the tongue) to make a clicking sound.
examples: My mother clucked her tongue in disapproval.

entries.meaning: To call together, or call to follow, as a hen does her chickens.
(Britain, drug slang) to suffer withdrawal from heroin.
